title: Michael Hintze goes back to basics
text:
Brexit is creating damaging uncertainty and might have implications for parliamentary democracy, but Hintze says it shouldn’t trouble investors with a broader horizon.

“The point is that Brexit feels important here [in London], but in the world as a whole it doesn’t really matter,” he says.

It’s an unusually sunny attitude for a specialist in the risk-conscious debt markets.

But it might be one worth heeding: the CQS Directional Opportunities fund, which Hintze personally manages, has returned 10.75 per cent this year, in a world of negative interest rates. And since the start of last year, CQS’s funds under management have risen by almost a quarter, to about $US18 billion ($26.8 billion).

What seems to set Hintze apart is his seemingly insatiable thirst for detail. He’s a genuine markets boffin. He reportedly likes nothing better than to sit in the “situation room” of CQS's London office and chew the fat about geopolitics, as part of his search for alpha.

Back to the floor

Now that he’s restructured the business he founded in 1999, which made him a billionaire and of which he was the sole boss for 19 years, he can indulge his inner boffin.

He hired Xavier Rolet, formerly head of the London Stock Exchange, as CEO at the end of last year, and in effect demoted himself: he’s now CQS’s “senior investment officer”, and sits at a standard open-plan trading desk in the middle of his team.

Advertisement

He still retains the title of executive chairman and is the controlling shareholder, but he’s happy to let Rolet pretty much run the show: product development, logistics and admin, client relationships.

The other week, he says, Rolet went to an investor conference in Japan, leaving Hintze himself free to potter around the Middle East looking at oil installations.

If I was knocked over by a bus today, it wouldn't be too flash but there would be a lot more resilience. — CQS executive chairman Sir Michael Hintze

“That’s great. Before, I was basically doing it all,” Hintze says. “He can go and focus on the strategy and executing that strategy. I do not want to get involved in that, to make his world more difficult ... I do the portfolio management and trading, which is what I want to do.”

It sounds like a logical step; but the thing is that in the market’s eyes, Hintze has been synonymous with CQS. He’s now 66, and though he’s not slowing down he does need to eliminate the risk that the business is all about him.

“If I’d been knocked over by a bus five years ago, it would have been a real issue. If I was knocked over by a bus today, it wouldn’t be too flash but there would be a lot more resilience,” he says.

His other motivation is his increasing worry that if you don’t keep a close eye on your clients, and on the office’s back end – Rolet’s two biggest jobs – your business can run into just as much trouble as if you make a few bad investments.

Advertisement

“You look at the Australian banks at the moment, they’re making money for their shareholders but the nonsense that happened off the back of operational risk – the compliance, the HR – that will kill your business. That’s a big deal,” Hintze says.

It would be a tall order for anyone to walk into Hintze’s self-built vehicle and take the wheel, particularly with Hintze still in the co-pilot’s seat. But Rolet and Hintze go back a long way.

“I’ve known Xavier Rolet since January 9th, 1984,” says Hintze. “We joined Goldman Sachs in New York together on the same day on the international trading desk, we were sitting closer than you and I are sitting right now. He joined from business school and I joined from Salomon Brothers.”

He says this has meant there’s a huge reservoir of trust, and he can let Rolet get on with the job. But with all that off his plate, what is Hintze focused on now?

That elusive yield

CQS's London office is decorated with some of its executive chairman's personal art collection. Ian Tuttle

The big challenge is to deliver returns in a world where $US12 trillion of bonds, almost a third of the global total, are negative-yielding.

How's he doing? Besides the Directional Opportunities fund he manages, CQS's long-only Credit Multi Asset fund has produced a 6.1 per cent return so far this year, and his ABS fund 6.9 per cent (a fair way short of its annualised return of 16.4 per cent since October 2006).

Advertisement

But he does have to ensure his clients are braced for the mark-to-market volatility that delivering such returns brings.

He recently told clients that the credit markets’ current preoccupations – growth, the quality of cash flows and leverage – had created an opening for counterinvesting at the junk end of the market.

“The relative outperformance of the higher end over the lower end of the capital structure … is providing us opportunities in high yield, especially in single-B and CCC-rated securities where we are able to identify value and idiosyncratic alpha based on fundamental analysis,” he wrote. (Alpha is the return over the benchmark in any asset class.)

“For the second half of 2019 I like short-dated structured credit, relative value strategies, regulatory capital relief trades and special situations, especially European distressed assets.”

The human eventually gets taken in by the computer. But the human and the computer, together, can always beat the computer. — Michael Hintze

CQS is often referred to as a hedge fund, but the company is at pains to point out that the majority of its funds are now in long-only strategies.

“We take that hedge fund DNA and apply it to the long-only business,” he says. That means “looking at disparate themes, trying to be more nimble in terms of how we move our portfolios around, being very happy to actively manage portfolios from one place to another. Active trading, benchmark agnostic.”

One of the reasons CQS has started to go long lies in the huge growth of passive investing, where the trading is algorithm-based.

Advertisement

“Machines are trading rather than people. And there’s been very large growth in algo trading. At the same time, there’s less capital put into the market-making community by the banks. So that’s gone down, passives have gone up, most algos will be mean-reverting … there’s a lot of noise, and it’s bloody hard to get an edge unless you think about a long-term theme.”

Quantum leap

He sees investors as voters, the market as a voting mechanism.

In the algo-trading era, the average holding period in the US market is about 24 seconds – “algos will potentially trade in and out, they can trade that capital anything up to 20 times a day. So they’ll swamp the votes that long-only guys have. That’s one of the reasons why active managers find it hard to perform”.

Hintze doesn’t think he can out-trade a machine, but he backs himself to “out-invest” it.

In chess, Deep Blue beat a human champion. But for Hintze, that’s only the start of the story. “The interesting thing about it, and one of the reasons we’re moving more into AI and machine learning, is that the human eventually gets taken in by the computer. But the human and the computer, together, can always beat the computer. That’s the next iteration,” he says.

For him, the human’s x-factor is imagination. He doesn’t think machines can size up geopolitics, for example.

But he’s not a luddite: his next step is quantum computing. A quantum chip makes instantaneous a risk analysis that right now takes hours or even days, potentially offering a significant time advantage.

“It enables you look at the whole matrix at once, rather than in a binary way. It’s not there yet though,” he says.

It sounds like Hintze still has plenty of unfinished business.
description: Michael Hintze, founder of $26.8b asset manager CQS, has handed over the CEO job to someone else. Why now, and what's on his mind?
